{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3244411,"name":"","username":"BonesOfGlue","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e36b37/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T05:08:57.113Z","cooked":"

Our team is considering cutting out custom gears for things like intakes, turrets, adjustable hoods, etc. For these applications, there isn’t really a high load on any of the gears afaik, so we were thinking of using some plastic material for these gears to save weight and also make it easier to cut. We have access to a CNC router, and were thinking of using materials along the lines of Delrin and HDPE, but we were wondering if any teams have experience with a similar application, and which materials and thicknesses they used for this, and if this is a viable strategy in general.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T05:08:57.113Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":462,"reads":673,"readers_count":672,"score":2449.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54811,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3244422,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T05:57:45.763Z","cooked":"

CAN you do it, probably. But, I would expect a few issues–be prepared to waste some material.

Weight–check the strength-weight ratio of plastics vs metals, especially for HDPE/Delrin/UHMW. Some of these can be pretty dense, and not as strong per se as aluminum or steel. You can probably get some more strength by using thicker material, but that comes at a weight penalty. You might not save much weight overall.

Strength–this one depends a lot on the loading. Turret? Probably not going to have a lot of loading if the turret is a) light and b) NOT sticking any part outside the robot. (If any part goes outside the robot, the question is “which tooth breaks first” rather than “do we break teeth”.) Shooter hood? Probably OK, unless we’re shooting bowling balls. Intake? Make like 20 gears, replace every match. Not necessarily from the intake load itself, but from getting beat up all match.
–Note for strength: Do yourself a favor and do a gear tooth stress analysis.

Accurate tooth profiles–just going to say to make darn sure you can actually cut the teeth accurately. This might mean a finer cutter than you’d normally use.

I’m going to be kinda blunt here: I’ve seen cast-iron gear teeth fail a couple stages of reduction (one of which was chain) back from the part of the arm that hit something hard. I’m not sure I’d trust any gear that isn’t metal in FRC, and I’m a little bit skeptical of the aluminum gears.

That said, if you were to make a sprocket or pulley instead, particularly for the turret base, you’d be on much safer ground. Those spread the load over multiple teeth, so you can use thinner material and save more weight.

Don’t get me wrong: It’s an interesting design exercise, and now would be a decent time to take a look at it. I just don’t think it’s going to work as well as one would hope.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T05:57:45.763Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":671,"readers_count":670,"score":194.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/2","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244427,"name":"Andrew Torrance","username":"Torrance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/torrance/{size}/152754_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T06:28:14.074Z","cooked":"

We’ve used plastic gears many times over the years. Here’s 3 different manufacturing methods and their uses:

Laser Cutting
In 2016 our hood extended with a servo driving a 1/4" delrin 20DP sector gear that was lasercut delrin. This is probably the weakest version (20DP and delrin), but because of the servo driving it, it didn’t move crazy fast and so loads were low and it was ok.

image1893×1493 93.7 KB

3D Printing
We very often 3D printed (Markforged Onyx) gears and especially pulleys. Pulleys work better when printed/plastic because many teeth of the pulley are meshing with the belt and transmitting the loads, versus just 1 tooth of the a gear.

Our 2020 and 2022 shooter hoods were 20DP 3D printed curved sector gears and worked great for getting a ton of reduction for a controllable hood with minimal parts. The 2020 hood even had a printed pinion gear. The 3D printed parts also served to fill the gap between the turret and the rollers on the hood when hood was extended.

Router
We cut a 10DP rack gear out of 1/4" polycarbonate for our 2023 floor cube intake. This enabled the intake to deploy with the rack+pinion and also be flexible polycarb to survive impacts. To be able to actually cut on a router with our smallest 3mm diameter endmill we had to modify the tooth profile, adding additional undercut to the teeth so the endmill would get all the way in.

image1920×654 148 KB

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T06:28:24.538Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":583,"readers_count":582,"score":461.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"Andrew Torrance","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/0/2/0240e98778fa9fe17bb3d079421390c4982dbdf9.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/5/d5beadd0315f73f2469a55e9d73c1a1bc21161f3.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":20}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22569,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":20}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":20,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244445,"name":"Mark Wasserman","username":"Mark_Wasserman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mark_wasserman/{size}/9677_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T12:24:13.827Z","cooked":"

We haven’t routed any, but we have printed whole gearboxes and put them in really bad situations (high load, high impact). When they fail you would see that the broken tooth gets “topped” and think “Man, if only that tooth was made from something stronger”. True, a stronger tooth would have helped but the main culprit was the teeth separating from bushing/bearing movement, shaft flex, and case spread.

Gears want to separate with extreme prejudice when under load. Put extra thought in how the gears are held together. In our case, we made the teeth as big as possible, as wide as possible, and revised the bushing and its support and it solved the problem.

Check out the Nexen roller pinion gear profile. Stronger than regular gears, easier to machine, no backlash.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T13:23:59.924Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":455,"readers_count":454,"score":201.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"sanddrag","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1082,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244475,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T13:49:00.135Z","cooked":"

@nuclearnerd may be able to offer some insight here. I believe 5406 has cut gears from delrin or UHMW at various times over the years for their robots.

One thing to consider when doing this, is what size gear is appropriate for your application. I’m not talking about tooth count necessarily, but rather something like a 10dp gear vs a 20dp gear.

Depending on the machines you have access to, cutting the standard FRC tooth profile (20dp, 14.5° pressure angle) is going to be challenging at best, impossible at worst.

Going to a larger tooth profile will make the part easier to machine, and also may better resist shearing a tooth off your gear.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T13:49:00.135Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":443,"readers_count":442,"score":123.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/6","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244482,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T14:08:35.027Z","cooked":"
cad321:

@nuclearnerd may be able to offer some insight here. I believe 5406 has cut gears from delrin or UHMW at various times over the years for their robots.

We’ve made turret gears from Delrin which is stiff and laser cuts really well. I imagine just about any laser cuttable plastic will work though, depending on what properties you want for the application (polycarb, UHMW, nylon, polypropylene…)

Nexen roller pinion gear profile

Impressive. They are even a Minnesota based company.
Nexen Group

Thank you for pointing this out!

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T14:27:32.085Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":398,"readers_count":397,"score":89.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"topgun","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.nexengroup.com/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":52}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10805,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244497,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T14:35:00.199Z","cooked":"

We’ve done a great many 3D printed pulleys with success, but I’m hard pressed to think of a situation where an actual plastic gear would be something we would try as we routinely see aluminum and even steel gears lose teeth due to shock loads. There are (as in posts above) a number of sort-of-gear-like applications (the rack of rack-and-pinion for example), where the design flexibility of plastic is a clear win though.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T14:35:00.199Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":392,"readers_count":391,"score":93.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/9","custom_user_title":"Opinions expressed are mine only","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244513,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T14:59:47.697Z","cooked":"
nuclearnerd:

We’ve made turret gears from Delrin

To illustrate, both the hood angle gears and azimuth gears (and the entire turret construction actually) are made from laser cut Delrin. The gear teeth on the back of the hood were 20DP, 20deg PA. The azimuth ring gear was 10DP, 20deg PA.

PXL_20220319_0515331581920×2560 611 KB

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T15:00:11.480Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":387,"readers_count":386,"score":137.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/5/6/56ac2ec0d0569937d82fefbcfcb31c3ffb821b24.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244517,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T15:06:16.237Z","cooked":"

We 3d printed a double-rack and gears on our claw last year out of PLA. Worked great.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T15:06:48.394Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":367,"readers_count":366,"score":168.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244532,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T15:57:14.826Z","cooked":"
Mark_Wasserman:

we made the teeth as big as possible, as wide as possible, and revised the bushing and its support and it solved the problem

cad321:

Going to a larger tooth profile will make the part easier to machine, and also may better resist shearing a tooth off your gear.

This

Don’t assume you can just drop in a plastic part for something that is designed with different material properties in mind.

Play to the strengths of the material, whether that be using the plastic’s flexibility for an engineered failure point, easy to manufacture with a router/3d printer (eg large teeth) , etc.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T15:59:04.537Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":101.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/12","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244537,"name":"Brendan Manning","username":"BrendanManning","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T16:05:15.036Z","cooked":"
john3928:

but I’m hard pressed to think of a situation where an actual plastic gear would be something we would try

It’s not really a location that would see load and there were a significant number of spots where 3DP gears backfired for us on the 777 robot, but one that worked well was our encoder mount. We were using the REV through bore encoder and connecting to max spline so we used a couple 3DP gears and a 3DP mount to connect it. Note that this was printed on a MarkForged, but I’d expect it could work with other materials.

image511×610 55.2 KB

We ran out of 14-tooth sprockets for powering our intake rollers so we used 3D printed copies. They held up through both District Events, District Championship and Houston Championship. I am pretty sure that they were printed using PLA.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T19:24:41.965Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":316,"readers_count":315,"score":78.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244730,"name":"Matt Golman","username":"BordomBeThyName","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T19:45:25.783Z","cooked":"

This looks a lot like 3476’s 2019 turret gear.

Team 3476: Code Orange 2019 “Cloudbreak” Robot Reveal Robot Showcase
[IMG_20190210_180803] [turret] We are using a custom-made roller pinion drive that basically consists of a pinion with rollers arranged in a circle and a large internal ring gear. The rollers are on bearings and rotate freely instead of sliding against the gear teeth, so it has very low friction. Due to the nature of the design, there is practically no backlash if it can be manufactured accurately. We made the ring gear on a CNC router and CNC milled the bearing holes on the pinion.

Oğuz Özgür","username":"oguzozgur","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oguzozgur/{size}/229514_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T21:31:00.818Z","cooked":"

This off-season, we built almost a direct copy of what we saw from 254. 10DP 6mm thick polycarb racks with steel gears for our intake’s activation. As far as I understand, plastic gears are ok for low torque- high speed applications. Even though our setup is very inefficient, this thing cooks in our eyes.

rack1920×1049 101 KB

Reasons for it being unoptimal:

  • We have a NEO 550 running it since we didn’t have a full size BLDC for it. (I love 550 for rollers.)

  • We have a VP gearbox and 3 (very tight) belts before the racks and pinions.

Beşiktaş Rsports 9483 | 2023 Off-season Build Blog

Adsız1152×774 316 KB

  • Gears meshing with the plastic racks are laser cut.
Beşiktaş Rsports 9483 | 2023 Off-season Build Blog

IMG_20230917_2109491920×1536 80 KB

  • We hand filed the polycarb teeth after CNC since our router sponsor didn’t have the needed diameter end mill. This comedic thing was our friction reduction process.
Beşiktaş Rsports 9483 | 2023 Off-season Build Blog

Stars were aligned for it to work bad, but this was the result we got with suboptimal tuning.

Beşiktaş Rsports 9483 | 2023 Off-season Build Blog

It even works fast enough for a 5 cube auto.

Beşiktaş Rsports 9483 | 2023 Off-season Build Blog

I don’t know how much lifetime this thing has or how will it take a beating in comp, but this journey has made me less biased against plastic gears. We need to up our material selection game.

We made our 2022 turret gear out of 1/4” polycarb on our router. It worked great, we drove it with an aluminum pinion made from an drivetrain gear that had lost all its teeth, the turret was used for 1 district through dcmp, cmp, and 4 off seasons with no wear or breakage problems. You will need to use very large teeth both for strength and to accommodate minimum internal radii. I believe we used 10DP (don’t quote me on that) and we still had to use a 1/16” router bit to avoid major changes to the root geometry.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-10-25T00:12:13.085Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":308,"readers_count":307,"score":66.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442969,"topic_slug":"cutting-gears-out-of-plastics","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/19","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244878,"name":"NickRandom","username":"NickRandom","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/cc9497/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-25T01:04:10.980Z","cooked":"

As others have said 3D printed gears work well for low torque, low speed, low shock situations. We have used them for turrets and hoods (inspired by some of the 254 designs above!). I would probably not recommend it for an intake though.

We also print 3D timing belt pulleys. One trick is to not 3D print a hex hub. Instead make the hub fit a small metal gear as this is much stronger. We have done this to mount a printed timing belt pulley directly to a motor with a pinion gear for a shooter.

For extra strength I have heard of people injecting epoxy into a 3D print. Apparently Team 4774 has done this.
